[[Timeform|Timeform rating]]: 137 {{cite web|url=http://www.americanclassicpedigrees.com/easy-goer.html |location=americanclassicpedigrees.com |title=Easy Goer (USA) |date=2014–2016 |accessdate=June 13, 2016}} |updated= June 13, 2016}} '''Easy Goer''' (March 21, 1986 – May 12, 1994) was an American [[Champion]] [[Hall of Fame]] [[Thoroughbred]] racehorse known for earning [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Colt]] honors in 1988 and defeating 1989 [[American Horse of the Year]] [[Sunday Silence]] in the [[Belmont Stakes]] by eight [[horse length|lengths]]. Both horses were later voted into the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|American Hall of Fame]]. The victory deprived Sunday Silence of the [[United States Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]]. It was also the second-fastest Belmont in history, behind only the record performance of [[Secretariat (horse)|Secretariat]] in 1973. Easy Goer was the first two-year-old champion to win a Triple Crown race since [[Spectacular Bid]] in 1979. Easy Goer also ran the fastest mile on dirt by any three-year-old in the history of [[Thoroughbred racing]] with a time of 1:32 2/5, which was a second faster than Secretariat's [[Stakes race|stakes]] record, and one-fifth of a second off of the world record set by [[Dr. Fager]] in 1968. Easy Goer is the only horse in racing history to win the Belmont, Whitney, Travers, Woodward and Jockey Club Gold Cup and the only 3-year-old to win the Whitney, Woodward and Jockey Club Gold Cup while defeating older horses in the latter three. Easy Goer is one of only two horses to win the Champagne, Belmont, and Travers. He is also one of only two horses to notch a Travers, Whitney and Belmont Stakes triple, and the only one to do so in the same year. Additionally, he is one of only five horses to tally a Whitney-Travers double in the same year. Since 1919, Easy Goer is one of only ten horses to sweep the Belmont, Travers and Jockey Club Gold Cup. Since 1973, Easy Goer is one of only seven horses that have won three consecutive Grade I races longer than 1 1/8 miles on dirt (or synthetic). On the [[Blood-Horse magazine List of the Top 100 U.S. Racehorses of the 20th Century|''Blood-Horse'' List of the Top 100 U.S. Racehorses of the 20th Century]], Easy Goer is ranked #34. ==Racing career== Bred and owned by [[Ogden Phipps]], Easy Goer was a son of [[Alydar]] out of the 1981 [[American Champion Older Female Horse]] Relaxing (by [[Buckpasser]]). Trained by [[Claude R. McGaughey III|Shug McGaughey]] and ridden by [[Pat Day]], the uncommonly muscular,{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/03/sports/notebook-easy-goer-hits-his-first-race-in-stride.html | work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=NOTEBOOK; Easy Goer Hits His First Race in Stride | date=March 3, 1989 |accessdate=August 16, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Lazzarino|first=Chris|title=Easy Goer Collapses, Dies|newspaper=Sun Sentinel|date=May 13, 1994|url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1994-05-13/sports/9405120793_1_easy-goer-trainer-shug-mcgaughey-stakes|accessdate=August 16, 2016}} big,{{cite web | url=http://articles.philly.com/1989-05-03/sports/26114950_1_liberty-bell-park-race-track-hot-walker-and-groom | work=The Philadelphia Inquirer| first=Russ | last=Harris| title=Walking Tall Shug Mcgaughey Has Come A Long Way From Liberty Bell | date=May 3, 1989 |accessdate=August 16, 2016}} powerful, long-striding{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YWGNmICO5OAC&pg=PA117&lpg=PA117&dq=easy+goer+powerful&source=bl&ots=7v6KopMqoK&sig=0Yb2UkL-DXPAM3GmDkRSyQsveLQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGt-LD_8XOAhVFpR4KHb_SDNc4ChDoAQgbMAA#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20powerful&f=false |title=Thoroughbred Champions: Top 100 Racehorses of the 20th Century |publisher=Blood-Horse Publications |author=Tom LaMarra |date=1999 |accessdate=August 16, 2016}} [[chestnut (coat)|chestnut]] [[Colt (horse)|colt]] with a white [[horse markings|star]] won 14 of his 20 races, including nine [[Graded stakes race|Grade I]] wins from distances of seven to twelve furlongs, and placed second five times. Easy Goer's racing career was also marked by his closely matched rivalry with Sunday Silence, who held a three to one edge in their head to head races.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iTJiAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA272&lpg=PA272&dq=easy+goer+new+york+horse&source=bl&ots=QEdb6jt7Vl&sig=bSJwa5TeWXc6GjRnp9V8c_Sl24w&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BJKUU4XYPISsyASio4HADw&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBThG#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20new%20york%20horse&f=false |title=The Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes: A Comprehensive History |publisher= MacFarland & Company, Inc. |author= Richard Sowers |accessdate= June 6, 2015}} Easy Goer defeated Sunday Silence by eight [[horse length|lengths]] in the Belmont and finished second to him in the Kentucky Derby by two and a half lengths, Preakness by a nose and Breeders' Cup Classic by a neck. Both horses were later voted into the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame|American Hall of Fame]]. McGaughey described Easy Goer as, "a big, strong horse, and jockey Pat Day helped him by not crucifying him in his races and bringing me back something. He had soundness problems, but we stayed on top of it.{{cite news | url=https://nypost.com/2003/08/17/midsummer-derby-is-second-to-none-historic-race-crowns-heroes-at-saratoga/ | work=The New York Post | first=Ed | last=Fountaine | title=Midsummer Derby is second to none: Historic race crowns heroes at Saratoga | date=August 17, 2003}} His action was so athletic, so natural, so fluid; he glided over the track; he ran very fast and did it so easily.{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19890504&id=frhPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vQYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6677,3524007&hl=en | work=Ocala Star-Banner | first=Steve | last=Davidowitz | title=Easy Goer draws lots of praise | date=May 4, 1989 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}} He captured the public; he was a brilliantly fast horse, exciting to watch, and he had a great following. I had always dreamed of having a horse like Easy Goer.{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/05/13/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-who-raced-to-public-fancy-dies-at-8.html | work=The New York Times | first=Joseph | last=Durso | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer, Who Raced to Public Fancy, Dies at 8 | date=May 13, 1994 |accessdate=July 14, 2016}} Easy Goer is by far the best that I've ever had."{{cite web | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-08-20/sports/sp-1371_1_easy-goer/2 | work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Travers Won on Late Run by Easy Goer | date=August 20, 1989 |accessdate=August 9, 2016}} Day stated, "Easy Goer was the best horse I ever rode. He was the most talented and he had a big engine and a lot of heart and desire. He did what he did with continuing ailments."{{cite news | url=http://www.horsenation.com/2013/10/21/a-blessed-life-pat-day-on-making-peace-with-his-sport-his-faith/ | work=Horse Nation | first=Grace | last=Van Dyke | title=A Blessed Life: Pat Day on making peace with his sport & his faith | date=October 21, 2013}}{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xMS_Yz0YOIwC&pg=PA60&lpg=PA60&dq=talkin+horses+pat+day&source=bl&ots=Aj7rdm4ibO&sig=C-drT7XEf-Gibe-EyFVWL-ePqG0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwigydj__YDLAhVCyT4KHRTLCN0Q6AEILTAD#v=onepage&q=talkin%20horses%20pat%20day&f=false |work=Blood-Horse Publications |first=Ron |last=Mitchell |title=Best of Talkin' Horses | date=2008}} Racing writer [[Steve Haskin]] described Easy Goer as "Adonis-like, the closest thing physically to Secretariat. He was plagued by terrible ankles his entire career, but was placed upon a throne at an early age and justified all the adoration.{{cite news | url=http://cs.bloodhorse.com/blogs/horse-racing-steve-haskin/archive/2014/03/03/the-selling-of-the-1989-triple-crown.aspx | work=Blood Horse Hangin' with Haskin | first=Steve | last=Haskin | title=The Selling of the 1989 Triple Crown | date=March 3, 2014}} Easy Goer was a horse with God-given talent who appeared to have everything – looks, class, pedigree, speed, and stamina."{{cite news | url=http://cs.bloodhorse.com/blogs/horse-racing-steve-haskin/archive/2013/05/06/derby-launched-into-orb-it.aspx | work=Blood Horse Hangin' with Haskin | first=Steve | last=Haskin | title=Derby Launched Into Orb-it | date=May 6, 2013 |accessdate=August 16, 2016}} Racing writer [[Edward L. Bowen]] said: "Easy Goer was a glowing chestnut with a fluid stride that belied his short pasterns and less than perfect foot. Pasterns notwithstanding, he had the look of greatness, and he ran to his looks.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i7ilgwjwtN4C&pg=PA182&lpg=PA182&dq=easy+goer+powerful&source=bl&ots=2uNopjOurE&sig=KwbvRDq3MM7HW34grllwTuIaKM4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZkucU7mKOMuuyATFq4KADA&ved=0CGwQ6AEwDA#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20powerful&f=false | work=Blood-Horse Publications | first=Edward | last=Bowen | title=Legacies of the Turf: A Century of Great Thoroughbred Breeders, Volume 2 | date=2004}} He was a horse who tempted horsemen and fans to slip into their thoughts the phrase, 'the most perfect horse you can imagine.' Easy Goer was large but not too large. He was elegant but not dainty. He was powerful but not gross. To the aesthete taking in the whole rather than haggling over the parts, the dictionary simply proved inadequate: Easy Goer was not just perfect, he was "damned perfect."{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LhVVOWZ5QR0C&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=easy+goer+century+of+champions+cover&source=bl&ots=FvPegyhYzP&sig=VY_vZY89WtXDqDLRpOs4ynTjgfQ&hl=en&sa=X&sqi=2&ved=0ahUKEwiIzPrQo_TNAhWKuB4KHX0DCIEQ6AEISzAI#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20century%20of%20champions%20cover&f=false |title=Belmont Park: A Century of Champions |publisher=Eclipse Press Blood-Horse publications |author=Edward L. Bowen and Richard Stone Reeves |accessdate=July 26, 2016}} Tom LaMarra, of Blood-Horse, wrote: "Easy Goer is mentioned in the same breath with some of the greatest horses of all time."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YWGNmICO5OAC&pg=PA117&lpg=PA117&dq=easy+goer+powerful&source=bl&ots=7v6KopMqoK&sig=0Yb2UkL-DXPAM3GmDkRSyQsveLQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGt-LD_8XOAhVFpR4KHb_SDNc4ChDoAQgbMAA#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20powerful&f=false |title=Thoroughbred Champions: Top 100 Racehorses of the 20th Century |publisher=Blood-Horse Publications |author=Tom LaMarra |date=1999 |accessdate=August 30, 2017}} [[Joe Drape]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' described Easy Goer as a "powerful, massive, raw talent with an enormous stride."{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xSmVkBQ0uaIC&pg=PA196&lpg=PA196&dq=easy+goer+powerful&source=bl&ots=rd63UAql1U&sig=3UEg7gJDr6sh-2lJK6UnToxp19Y&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dKOdU6LfEYyoyASsw4GoBw&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20powerful&f=false | work=The New York Times Company | first=Joe | last=Drape | title=To the Swift: Classic Triple Crown Horses and Their Race for Glory | date=2008}} Hall of Fame trainer [[John M. Veitch|John Veitch]] stated, "Easy Goer had more weapons and was more versatile than his father Alydar."{{cite news | url=http://alb.merlinone.net/mweb/wmsql.wm.request?oneimage&imageid=5514002 | work=Times Union | first=Keith | last=Marder | title=2 TRAINERS, 2 HORSES, 2 SECONDS | date=June 10, 1989 |accessdate=August 8, 2016}} [[Bud Delp]], trainer of Spectacular Bid, said, "I hadn't seen the kind of pistonlike action in a horse since Spectacular Bid. Easy Goer had the same kind of stride, which was effortless."{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19890414&id=0HghAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EIkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=932,3303928&hl=en | work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Best colt since Spectacular Bid, says Delp - Easy Goer could win Triple Crown | date=April 14, 1989 |accessdate=August 8, 2016}} His running style was multifaceted and flexible, and he was able to adjust to racing conditions;{{cite news | url=http://articles.philly.com/1989-08-21/sports/26150883_1_easy-goer-clever-trevor-shug-mcgaughey | work=The Inquirer | first=Dick | last=Jerardi | title=Easy Goer Lives Up To Expectations At Travers | date=August 21, 1989}}{{cite news | url=http://articles.philly.com/1989-08-18/sports/26149949_1_easy-goer-clever-trevor-race-track | work=The Inquirer | first=Dick | last=Jerardi | title=Easy Goer Challenge: Outfox Clever Trevor | date=August 18, 1989}} he could go to the lead or come from behind,{{cite news | url=http://alb.merlinone.net/mweb/wmsql.wm.request?oneimage&imageid=5514002 | work=Times Union | first=Keith | last=Marder | title=2 TRAINERS, 2 HORSES, 2 SECONDS | date=June 10, 1989}} he was able to put pressure on speed horses and stay with a faster pace, or drop back if needed.{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-08/sports/sp-132_1_easy-goer | work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Paul | last=Moran | title=HORSE RACING : Easy Goer Is Poised for Arlington | date=July 8, 1990}} He possessed both speed and stamina.{{cite news |url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/51883/funny-moon-bred-on-miler-over-stamina-model |work=Blood Horse | first=Avalyn | last=Hunter | title=Funny Moon Bred on Miler-Over-Stamina Model | date=July 29, 2009}} Among his peak performances, Easy Goer ran 124 and 122 [[Beyer Speed Figure]]s.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-11-10/sports/sp-63476_1_cigar-races-horses | work=Washington Post | first=Andrew | last=Beyer | title=Overacheiver Cigar Had a Mark of Consistency | date=November 10, 1996}} He also consistently ran in the 120 speed figure range on a regular basis in his races.{{cite news | url=https://www.drf.com/news/beyer-figs-get-human-touch | work=Daily Racing Form | first=Dick | last=Jerardi | title=Beyer figs get human touch | date=August 24, 2005}} Furthermore, he ran the fastest Beyer Speed Figure performance by any two-year-old, as well as the fastest Beyer Speed Figure performance in any Triple Crown race since Beyer racing figures were first published.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/08/AR2008020803619.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Andrew | last=Beyer | title=With a Combination of Speed and Class, War Pass Is Reminiscent of Seattle Slew | date=February 9, 2008}}{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A31625-2004May16.html |work=The Washington Post | first=Andrew | last=Beyer | title=On the Fast Track To History | date=May 17, 2004}} ===1988: two-year-old season=== Before his career began, Easy Goer was shipped to McGaughey at the Payson Park Training Center in [[Indiantown, Florida]], where he spent the winter getting acquainted with the [[starting gate]] and underwent basic training. His trainer noted some faults in his [[equine conformation|conformation]]. He had puffy, problematic [[fetlock|ankles]],{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-11-08/sports/sp-1011_1_easy-goer|title=HORSE RACING : Maybe It's Time Easy Goer Gets a Different Rider |accessdate=2013-04-21}} a [[clubfoot]], and a turned-out left knee, all providing the potential for injury once the horse began serious workouts.{{cite news| url=https://www.si.com/vault/1989/05/08/106780239/a-tale-of-two-horse | work=Sports Illustrated | first=Demmie | last=Stathoplos | title=A Tale Of Two Horse | date=May 8, 1989}} However, McGaughey was captivated with Easy Goer the first time he saw him, but really felt he had something special when he watched him for the first time with a set of horses. "He gave the impression he could gallop those horses to death," McGaughey said. At age two, Easy Goer won his [[maiden race]] at seven [[furlong]]s at [[Saratoga Race Course]] under a hand ride in a final time of 1:22 3/5, defeating [[Is It True (horse)|Is It True]] by two and a half lengths after being forwardly placed two lengths off the early leaders and having to steady on the backstretch, and, as McGaughey stated, "Running two or three seconds faster than the other maiden race run at the same distance that day at Saratoga."{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/sports/choice-fame-easy-article-1.771584 | work=Daily News |first=Sherry |last=Ross |title=CHOICE FOR FAME VERY EASY |date=August 5, 1997 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}} Easy Goer's time was notably impressive taking into account that it was approximately fifteen lengths faster than that aforementioned maiden race run at the same distance that day at Saratoga.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/12/sports/sports-of-the-times-phipps-s-barn-is-the-home-of-the-stars.html | work=The New York Times |first=Steven |last=Crist |title=SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Phipps's Barn Is the Home of the Stars |date=September 12, 1988 |accessdate=July 28, 2016}} Easy Goer came out of that race with a sore left [[cannon bone|shin]]. McGaughey was concerned because he thought he might have to stop the colt's training; however, treatment by hosing and [[poultice|poulticing]] the leg to draw out the heat was successful. McGaughey decided to wait and have Easy Goer's legs further treated after the [[Breeders' Cup]] that November. Easy Goer continued to train at Saratoga. He then won a 6 1/2 furlong [[allowance race]] by five and a half lengths at [[Belmont Park]], again under little urging, running one-fifth of a second off the track record in 1:15 2/5, while carrying five pounds more than his opponents. Easy Goer's time was particularly exceptional considering that on the same day at Belmont, older allowance horses ran the same distance just under two seconds slower.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/12/sports/sports-of-the-times-phipps-s-barn-is-the-home-of-the-stars.html | work=The New York Times |first=Steven |last=Crist |title=SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Phipps's Barn Is the Home of the Stars |date=September 12, 1988 |accessdate=July 26, 2016}} His trainer said after the race, "Then I knew I was training something special." Easy Goer next won the seven-furlong [[Graded stakes race|Grade I]] [[Cowdin Stakes]] with little encouragement, defeating Is It True again by four lengths. Easy Goer was never more than three and a half lengths behind the early leaders, who ran quick early fractions of 22 2/5 and 45 3/5, before drawing away through the stretch. He also defeated [[Canadian Champion Two-Year-Old Colt]] Mercedes Won, who was the [[Hopeful Stakes]] and [[Florida Derby]] winner. He ran the seven furlongs in 1:23 3/5. The final time was more than two seconds off Devil's Bag's 1983 stakes record, but the Belmont track was producing uncommonly slow times that day.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/02/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-captures-cowdin.html | location=New York | work=New York Times | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Captures Cowdin }} Two weeks later Easy Goer won the $557,000 one-mile Grade I [[Champagne Stakes (USA)|Champagne Stakes]] with little exertion, again defeating Is It True by four lengths, after vying for command and running a half length to a length and a half behind the leader through fast fractions of 22 4/5 and 45 3/5. He also defeated the [[Belmont Futurity]] winner Trapp Mountain and [[Young America Stakes]] winner Irish Actor. His 1:34 4/5 final time for the mile was three-fifths of a second off the Champagne stakes record, and tied for fourth-fastest in Champagne Stakes history behind Vitriolic, [[Seattle Slew]] (1:34 2/5), and [[Devil's Bag]] (1:34 1/5). In the [[Frizette Stakes]] run at the same distance that day at Belmont, future Hall of Fame champion [[Open Mind (horse)|Open Mind]] fell a nose short of catching Some Romance at the wire. Some Romance ran the mile in 1:36 4/5, two seconds, or approximately 12 lengths, slower than Easy Goer.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/16/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-wins-champagne.html | location=New York | work=New York Times | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Wins Champagne}} Additionally, in this Champagne Stakes, Easy Goer ran the fastest [[Beyer Speed Figure]] performance (116 Beyer){{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rztm-KHHBt4C&pg=PA185&lpg=PA185&dq=easy+goer+beyers&source=bl&ots=NtvS5CO5Bf&sig=qBlpjm_UNwJ5noTncaWJi8ZzYEA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sSaNU6CTGrC-sQTF3YKABg&sqi=2&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20beyers&f=false |work=Beyer on Speed | first=Andrew | last=Beyer | title=Beyer on Speed | date=1993}} of any two-year-old since Beyer racing figures were first published. Racing analyst [[Andrew Beyer]] stated, "Easy Goer was the most brilliant American two-year-old of the decade."{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rztm-KHHBt4C&pg=PA185&lpg=PA185&dq=easy+goer+beyers&source=bl&ots=NtvS5CO5Bf&sig=qBlpjm_UNwJ5noTncaWJi8ZzYEA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=sSaNU6CTGrC-sQTF3YKABg&sqi=2&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=easy%20goer%20beyers&f=false |work=Beyer on Speed | first=Andrew | last=Beyer | title=Beyer on Speed | date=1993 |accessdate=July 26, 2016}} Racing writer Steven Crist stated, "Easy Goer is among the fastest two-year-olds of the last two decades."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/10/31/sports/breeders-cup-three-stars-will-be-racing-for-more-than-just-a-victory.html | work=The New York Times |first=Steven |last=Crist |title=Breeders' Cup; Three Stars Will Be Racing For More Than Just a Victory |date=October 31, 1988 |accessdate=July 26, 2016}} He finished second by a little more than a length in his last race of his two-year-old season, the Grade 1 [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile]] on a muddy track at Churchill Downs. He lost to Is It True, a horse he had defeated three times earlier in the year by a combined ten and a half lengths, having jumped the tire tracks left by the [[starting gate]] late in the homestretch, and seemed to be struggling and uncomfortable with the muddy Churchill track.{{cite news| url=http://www.breederscup.com/history-tradition/hall-champions/it-true | location=breederscup.com | work=breederscup.com | title=history/hall of champions -Homepage - breederscup.com}} He earned $697,500 and was named [[Eclipse Award|Champion two-year-old colt]] and was the early favorite for the [[Kentucky Derby]]. After the Breeders' Cup, he was shipped to New York to have his shins [[pinfiring|pinfired]], and then sent to [[Gulfstream Park]] in [[Hallandale, Florida]], to recuperate. ===1989: three-year-old season=== At three, Easy Goer started his year in [[Florida]] by winning the [[Swale Stakes]] in the fastest seven furlongs of the [[Gulfstream Park]] meeting in a time of 1:22 1/5 while carrying ten pounds more than the runner up. He "exploded" around the far turn to an almost nine length win defeating [[Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes]] and [[Nassau County Stakes]] winner Tricky Creek.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/03/05/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-rallies-to-win-the-swale.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Rallies To Win The Swale | date=March 5, 1989}} He then won the one mile [[graded stakes race|Grade II]] [[Gotham Stakes]] by thirteen lengths in stakes and track record time while conceding nine pounds and five pounds to the second and third-place finishers respectively, including future world record holder (on turf at one mile) [[Expensive Decision]], winner of the [[Kelso Handicap]] and [[Saranac Handicap]]. He ran within one to two lengths of the leaders throughout the race, who were running a very rapid pace of 44 1/5 and 1:08 3/5, before running past them and widening away. He won [[Glossary of North American horse racing#H|handily]] and his winning time of 1:32 2/5 for the mile set a new track record, a second faster than Secretariat's stakes record, the fastest mile on a dirt surface by any three-year-old [[Thoroughbred]] in history, and a fifth of a second off [[Dr. Fager]]'s world record. Easy Goer's unofficial gallop-out time of 1:45 4/5 for 1 1/8 miles, was 1 1/5 seconds faster than the track record set in 1973 by [[Riva Ridge]], and only two fifths of a second slower than Secretariat's former nine-furlong world record on dirt set in the 1973 [[Marlboro Cup]].{{cite news| url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/21737/on-this-day |work=Bloodhorse.com | first=Bill | last=Finley |title=On This Day... | date=April 7, 2004}} His next race was the mile and an eighth Grade I [[Wood Memorial]], which in 1989 was run two weeks after the Gotham Stakes and two weeks before the Kentucky Derby. Easy Goer ran close to the lead the entire race and won by three lengths over [[Federico Tesio Stakes]] winner Rock Point. He was timed in a relatively moderate 1:50 3/5. However, students of time pointed out that Aqueduct was playing about two seconds slower than normal on the day.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-04-23/sports/sp-1859_1_easy-goer-diamond-donnie-wood-memorial |work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Wood Memorial : Easy Goer's 3-Length Victory Is Impressive but Not Spectacular | date=April 23, 1989}} ===Rivalry with Sunday Silence=== Easy Goer was most remembered for his rivalry with Sunday Silence. The two first met in the [[1989 Kentucky Derby]] where Sunday Silence won by 2½ lengths over Easy Goer in the relatively slow time of 2:05 on a muddy track similar to the Breeders' Cup Juvenile the previous year. Easy Goer had a small crack in his left front heel that was found the week leading into the Kentucky Derby. The crack was serious enough to cause discomfort and possibly keep him from running.{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19890518&id=omIhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cIgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1190,4983781 |work=Schenectady Gazette | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=McGaughey decides not to run Easy Goer on bute in Preakness | date=May 18, 1989}} Easy Goer had a history for his difficulty to handle a muddy track at Churchill Downs and seemed to be struggling with the footing.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/10/sports/belmont-stakes-a-wet-track-could-dampen-bid-for-crown.html|publisher=New York Times|title=BELMONT STAKES; A Wet Track Could Dampen Bid for Crown|date=1989-06-10|accessdate=2013-04-20}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19890612&id=N-lRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zm4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6837,3523505|title=Day finally steers Easy Goer right|accessdate=2013-04-21}} Easy Goer also had traffic trouble in the race, being cut off by Northern Wolf during the first quarter-mile, causing him to check, and Dansil drifted into his path in the final eighth of a mile in the home stretch, causing Easy Goer to alter course. Multiple Grade I winner Awe Inspiring finished third. Sunday Silence won the Derby despite not keeping a straight path through the stretch while 2½ lengths in front at the finish line.{{cite news | url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-05-07/sports/8901240057_1_easy-goer-santa-anita-derby-115th-kentucky-derby | work=Sun Sentinel | first=Dave | last=Joseph | title=A Moment Of 'Silence' Sunday Silence Upsets Easy Goer In The Mud | date=May 7, 1989}}{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/07/sports/horse-racing-sunday-silence-takes-derby-in-upset.html | work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Sunday Silence Takes Derby in Upset | date=May 7, 1989}} After the Derby, both horses returned to action two weeks later in the [[1989 Preakness Stakes]]. Throughout Preakness week, as late as the day before the race, Easy Goer's front feet were being soaked in a tub of [[Epsom salts]] due to small scratches or cracks on both heels. His ankles and knees were also given ultrasound.{{cite news | url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-05-20/sports/8901260263_1_shug-mcgaughey-silence-preakness-stakes | work=Sun Sentinel | first=Dave | last= Joseph |title=Looking For Word To Whys Will Easy Goer Have Answers? | date=May 20, 1989}} Easy Goer, after breaking in the air at the start, made a big, early move down the backstretch which catapulted him to a two-length lead over Sunday Silence with a half mile remaining, with the six-furlong split being run in a rapid 1:09 3/5. Sunday Silence then challenged around the far turn, with both horses running the fastest mile split in Preakness history in 1:34 1/5. Following a nose-to-nose duel for the last quarter mile with Easy Goer running in very tight quarters near the rail, Sunday Silence won by a nose in a fast final time of 1:53 4/5. Jockey [[Pat Day]] was criticized for reining Easy Goer's head sideways to the right in deep stretch with a short lead right before the finish line. Day criticized himself, calling his ride "a mistake." Bill Christine of the Los Angeles Times, and trainer McGaughey also expressed their opinions on the mistakes they thought Day made during the race.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-05/sports/sp-1157_1_easy-goer-bill-shoemaker-laffit-pincay|title=It Was a Difference of Styles in the Preakness : Valenzuela's Aggressive Western Riding Overwhelmed Day's Eastern Patience |accessdate=2013-04-21}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19890612&id=N-lRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zm4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6837,3523505|title=Day finally steers Easy Goer right |accessdate=2013-04-21}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1345&dat=19890608&id=tFhYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6vkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6754,1321166|title=Easy Goer gets last shot |accessdate=2013-04-21}} After the race, Day went to McGaughey's barn at Pimlico, after he had been criticized for his ride. Day said, "It ran through my mind that I might lose the mount on Easy Goer," Day said. "But then I shared some thoughts--I won't tell you what--with Shug and I felt better."{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-11/sports/sp-3372_1_easy-goer-shug-mcgaughey-triple-crown-race | work=The Los Angeles Times |first=Bill |last=Christine |title=THE BELMONT : Notes : Sunday Silence and Easy Goer May Not Meet Again Until Fall |date=June 11, 1989 |accessdate=July 26, 2016}} After the Preakness, both rivals returned to action three weeks later in the [[1989 Belmont Stakes]].{{cite web|url=http://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/run_for_the_carnations_belmont_stakes/ |title=Run for the Carnations|publisher=barrypopik.com|date=2010-04-30|accessdate=June 13, 2016}} During that era, New York was the only state in America that banned all race-day drugs and medications; New York didn't allow horses to race on any drugs, while the rest of the country did.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-08-03/sports/sp-586_1_easy-goer |work=Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Horse Racing : King Glorious to Skip Travers, and Easy Goer | date=August 3, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-15/sports/sp-2547_1_shelly-meredith-triple-crown-races | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Horse Racing / Bill Christine : Hawkster Wins the Triple Crown of Mediocrity | date=June 15, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-06-06/sports/sp-581_1_summer-squall |work=Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Lasix Debate Steals Belmont Spotlight : Horse racing: New York prohibits use of the diuretic to treat horses, in effect keeping bleeders such as Summer Squall away | date=June 6, 1990 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}} The trainer of Sunday Silence, [[Charlie Whittingham]], was angered that the controversial veterinarian Alex Harthill, who treated Sunday Silence earlier for the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, was not licensed in New York and prohibited from practicing.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1989/06/11/new-york-still-bars-harthill/86b9ba1a-24c1-4f6a-9d26-99597e371d03/ | work=Washington Post | first=Vinnie | last=Perrone | title=NEW YORK STILL BARS HARTHILL | date=June 11, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/09/sports/belmont-stakes-the-big-two-will-go-head-to-head-at-the-start.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=BELMONT STAKES; The Big Two Will Go Head to Head at the Start | date=June 9, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}} Both Easy Goer and Sunday Silence ran in close attendance to the pace-setting leader through swift early fractions, with Easy Goer making his move around the turn propelling himself to the lead; he then opened up a substantial lead through the stretch. Easy Goer defeated Sunday Silence by eight lengths in the time of 2:26 {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/11/sports/belmont-stakes-an-appropriate-reaction-from-whittingham-silence.html |title=BELMONT STAKES; An Appropriate Reaction From Whittingham: Silence - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1989-06-11 |accessdate=2011-12-29}} producing the second fastest Belmont Stakes in history, behind [[Secretariat (horse)|Secretariat]], and denied Sunday Silence the Triple Crown.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/11/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-finally-beats-sunday-silence.html |title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Finally Beats Sunday Silence - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1989-06-11 |accessdate=2011-12-29}} Easy Goer became the first two-year-old champion to win a Triple Crown race since Spectacular Bid in 1979. In the process, Easy Goer seemed to vindicate his reputation as the reigning champion two year-old. The jockey of Sunday Silence, Pat Valenzuela, described Easy Goer's performance as that of a superhorse. The race was run over a fast but not unusually quick track. Easy Goer earned a 122 [[Beyer Speed Figure]], the best in any Triple Crown race since these ratings were first published in 1987. ===Remainder of season=== Easy Goer went on that year to win the mile and an eighth Grade I [[Whitney Handicap]] at Saratoga, defeating older horses by over four lengths in near record time. The older horses he defeated in this Whitney were: [[Cryptoclearance]], earner of just under $3.4 million and winner of the [[Donn Handicap]], [[Pegasus Stakes]] and [[Widener Handicap]]; [[Brooklyn Handicap]], Nassau County and [[Excelsior Handicap]] winner Forever Silver; [[Stuyvesant Handicap]], [[Queens County Handicap]] and [[Stymie Handicap]] winner It's Academic; and [[Fayette Handicap]] and [[Ben Ali Handicap]] winner Homebuilder. He missed the stakes and track record in the Whitney by 2/5 of a second. The record was then held by Tri Jet, the only horse to ever run a faster Whitney than Easy Goer. Easy Goer earned the time even though he steadied while being trapped and boxed in around the far turn, and running his last eighth of a mile in eleven and two-fifth seconds.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/06/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-rallies-to-win-whitney.html |work=The New York Times |first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Rallies to Win Whitney | date=August 6, 1989}} McGaughey said after the race, "I don't know if I've ever seen a horse run the last eighth of a mile that fast going long on the dirt. Sometimes, you see it on the grass when a horse has gone a slow paced mile." Two weeks later at Saratoga, he won the $1.08 million mile and a quarter Grade I [[Travers Stakes]] over Grade I [[Arlington Classic]] winner Clever Trevor with moderate effort by three lengths also in near record time. He missed the Travers record by 4/5 of a second. It was the third fastest in Travers history, behind [[General Assembly (horse)|General Assembly]] and [[Honest Pleasure]].{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/20/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-takes-travers-by-3-lengths.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Takes Travers by 3 Lengths | date=August 20, 1989}} Trainer [[Jerry Hollendorfer]] decided to skip the Travers with [[Haskell Invitational Stakes]] and [[Hollywood Futurity]] winner King Glorious primarily because, during that era, [[New York (state)|New York]] banned all race-day drugs and medications, and King Glorious had been treated with [[Lasix]] in all nine of his races. New York didn't allow horses to race on any drugs, while the rest of the country did.{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-08-03/sports/sp-586_1_easy-goer |work=Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Horse Racing : King Glorious to Skip Travers, and Easy Goer | date=August 3, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-15/sports/sp-2547_1_shelly-meredith-triple-crown-races | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Horse Racing / Bill Christine : Hawkster Wins the Triple Crown of Mediocrity | date=June 15, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-06-06/sports/sp-581_1_summer-squall |work=Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Lasix Debate Steals Belmont Spotlight : Horse racing: New York prohibits use of the diuretic to treat horses, in effect keeping bleeders such as Summer Squall away | date=June 6, 1990 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}} The trainer of Sunday Silence, [[Charlie Whittingham]], may have chose to skip the Travers because he was angered that the controversial veterinarian Alex Harthill, who treated Sunday Silence earlier in the year, was not licensed in New York and prohibited from practicing.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1989/06/11/new-york-still-bars-harthill/86b9ba1a-24c1-4f6a-9d26-99597e371d03/ | work=Washington Post | first=Vinnie | last=Perrone | title=NEW YORK STILL BARS HARTHILL | date=June 11, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/09/sports/belmont-stakes-the-big-two-will-go-head-to-head-at-the-start.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=BELMONT STAKES; The Big Two Will Go Head to Head at the Start | date=June 9, 1989 |accessdate=July 6, 2016}} He also may have chose to skip the Travers to rest the horse, as he didn't run Sunday Silence in any race during that month of August. Easy Goer then won the $809,000 mile and a quarter Grade I [[Woodward Stakes]] by two lengths on a muddy track, again defeating older horses while carrying more weight and being stuck in traffic, boxed in on the rail and checking hard twice. Easy Goer's victory seemingly squashed the perception that muddy or wet tracks were his Achilles' heel. Day said after the race, "Mud is different everywhere." The older horses he defeated in this Woodward were: [[Metropolitan Handicap]], [[Arkansas Derby]] and [[Philip H. Iselin Stakes]] winner Proper Reality; and [[Oaklawn Handicap]] and [[Gulfstream Park Handicap]] winner Slew City Slew. This was the final time the Woodward was run at the mile and a quarter distance before being permanently shortened in distance to a mile and an eighth.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/17/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-proves-he-s-no-1.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Proves He's No. 1 | date=September 17, 1989}} Three weeks later, he won the $1.09 million mile and a half Grade I [[Jockey Club Gold Cup]] by four lengths, again defeating older horses, included among them were the aforementioned Cryptoclearance, who finished second. He also defeated [[Breeders' Cup Turf]] and [[Molson Export Million]] winner [[Prized]] by over 20 lengths in this race, a horse who had defeated Sunday Silence earlier in the year in the Grade II [[Swaps Stakes]]. The track was playing dull and slow, but despite the dullness of the racing surface, moderate pace, and relatively slow final time, he ran his sixth and final quarter-mile his fastest, coming home in 24.12 seconds. This was the final time the Jockey Club Gold Cup was run at the mile and a half distance prior to being permanently shortened in distance to a mile and a quarter.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/08/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-surges-to-win-gold-cup.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Surges To Win Gold Cup | date=October 8, 1989}} The rivalry with Sunday Silence concluded in the [[Breeders' Cup Classic]], run on November 4 at 1¼ miles. With champion honors at stake, the race was labeled "Race of the Decade" by the horse racing media. Easy Goer was favored by the wagering public based on his Belmont Stakes win and four subsequent Grade I wins, three against older horses. Sunday Silence's regular rider, [[Patrick Valenzuela]], had recently been suspended for cocaine use. Trainer [[Charles E. Whittingham]] assigned the mount to [[Chris McCarron]]. Easy Goer came into the 10-furlong Classic off the 12-furlong Gold Cup—a potentially tricky parlay for a trainer, because the longer race can have the dangerous effect of dulling the colt's natural speed and blunting the quickness that he might need in a shorter race.{{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1989/11/13/120995/silence-roars-once-more-in-the-race-for-horse-of-the-year-sunday-silence-outran-easy-goer-in-the-breeders-cup-classic | work=Sports Illustrated | first=William | last=Nack | title=Silence Roars Once More | date=November 13, 1989}} In contrast, trainer Charlie Whittingham had run Sunday Silence only twice in the five months since the Belmont, both times over a 1¼-mile distance—in the Grade II [[Swaps Stakes]] at [[Hollywood Park Racetrack|Hollywood Park]], where he finished second, and two months later in the Sept. 24 [[Super Derby]] at [[Louisiana Downs]], which he won. Easy Goer ran 11 lengths off the lead, about seven lengths behind Sunday Silence, behind the brisk opening fractions of 22:2/5 and 46:1/5, but made a big run down the backstretch and got near his rival at the half-mile point. Sunday Silence then made a charge turning for home and gained the lead in the final furlong, four lengths ahead of Easy Goer. Easy Goer closed ground late with another big move but lost by a diminishing neck to Sunday Silence, who was under strong urging by McCarron, with a final time of 2:00 1/5. [[Blushing John]], the [[American Champion Older Dirt Male Horse]] that year, finished behind the top two in third. The victory assured Sunday Silence [[Eclipse Award for Outstanding Three-Year-Old Male Horse]] and Horse of the Year honors for 1989. After the race, McGaughey said, "Sunday Silence had a perfect trip and we made a couple of mistakes. Pat and I agree that he made riding mistakes in the Preakness. But in the other races, there were circumstances that contributed to what happened. Maybe when Pat grabbed him after the start, the horse didn't understand what he was doing. Then Pat was content to sit and wait behind Sunday Silence, as he had done before, and the other horse got away from us.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-11-06/sports/sp-723_1_easy-goer | work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Bill | last=Christine | title=Sounds of Silence Make It Difficult for McGaughey : Horse Racing: The day after losing the Breeders' Cup Classic to Sunday Silence, Easy Goer's trainer is feeling blue. | date=November 6, 1989}} In my heart, I think Easy Goer is the better horse;{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-11-05/sports/8902080519_1_easy-goer-shug-mcgaughey-breeders |title=Losing The Big One Never Easy For Mcgaughey |publisher=Sun-sentinel.com |date=1989-11-05 |accessdate=July 15, 2016 |first=Michael |last=Mayo}} I think anybody would say that if those two ran against each other ten times, each would probably win five."{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1992-10-28/sports/9202260210_1_easy-goer-shug-mcgaughey-breeders-cup |title='89 Race Haunts Trainer Sunday Silence Still Casts Shadow |publisher=Sun-sentinel.com |date=October 28, 1992 |accessdate=July 15, 2016 |first=Chris |last=Lazzarino}} Day said his ride wasn't the best,{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-11-05/sports/8902080519_1_easy-goer-shug-mcgaughey-breeders |title=Losing The Big One Never Easy For Mcgaughey |publisher=Sun-sentinel.com |date=1989-11-05 |accessdate=2016-02-14 |first=Michael |last=Mayo}} while also stating, "I've said it before, I think Easy Goer was better than Sunday Silence, despite his three to one edge in the head to head races.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-27/sports/sp-737_1_easy-goer | work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Jay | last=Hovdey | title=For That Happy Traveler Sunday Silence, Getting There Is More Than Half the Fun | date=July 27, 1990}} I'll go to my grave believing that. We lost two photos to him and the one in the Preakness was due to a rider error on my part."{{cite web|url=https://www.americasbestracing.net/the-sport/2016-racings-unforgettable-rivalries-sunday-silence-and-easy-goer | location=americasbestracing.net | work=americasbestracing.net | first=Bob | last=Ehalt | title=Racing's Unforgettable Rivalries: Sunday Silence and Easy Goer | date=June 8, 2016 | accessdate=July 15, 2016}} Current [[Daily Racing Form]] publisher Steven Crist stated in his ''New York Times'' article in January 1990 that had the question on the ballot been, "Who is the better horse, Sunday Silence or Easy Goer?", his view was that a lot more than 19 people would have voted against Sunday Silence.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/sports/on-horse-racing-sunday-silence-does-the-expected.html |title=HORSE RACING; Sunday Silence does the expected - New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1990-01-30 |accessdate=2011-12-30 |first=Steven |last=Crist}} Crist also went on to state, "Easy Goer was a great horse and so was Sunday Silence. I still think Easy Goer had more pure, raw talent.{{cite news|url=http://brooklynbackstretch.com/2009/05/28/the-late-great-easy-goer/ | work=Brooklyn Backstretch | first=Teresa | last=Genaro | title=The late, great Easy Goer | date=May 28, 2009}} Sunday Silence held the three to one edge over Easy Goer in the races they met, but he never beat him in a way that proved he was just plain better. In Easy Goer's best race, he walloped Sunday Silence by eight lengths in the Belmont. In a few of his close defeats, Easy Goer had legitimate excuses: he lost the Derby on a muddy track he had difficulty handling, and lost the Preakness by only a nose after a dubious ride. In the Classic, where Sunday Silence held him off by a neck, Easy Goer just missed, but left no one thinking it could not have gone the other way."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/sports/on-horse-racing-closing-the-chapter-on-easy-goer.html?scp=6&sq=easy%20goer%20secretariat&st=cse | work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=ON HORSE RACING; Closing the Chapter on Easy Goer | date=July 24, 1990}} Daily Racing Form's Mike Watchmaker concurred, stating, "To this day, you won't have any trouble finding people who believe that Easy Goer was a better racehorse than Sunday Silence. I know this, because I am one of them."{{cite news|url=http://www.drf.com/news/rivalry-history-making |accessdate=2016-02-14 | work=Daily Racing Form | first=Mike |last=Watchmaker |title=Rivalry is history in the making |date=January 18, 2010}} "Paul Moran of the ''Los Angeles Times'' and ''Newsday'' agreed, stating, "Sunday Silence is Horse of the Year, but most still believe Easy Goer is the better horse. Sunday Silence is Horse of the Year despite never having won at a mile and a half (the classic distance for most of the world) and never having given weight while defeating older horses, as Easy Goer did in three races. He is Horse of the Year despite going one for three during a span of five months while Easy Goer won the Belmont, Whitney, Travers, Woodward and Jockey Club Gold Cup."{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-11-21/sports/sp-440_1_easy-goer |accessdate=2013-04-18 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Paul |last=Moran |title=RACING VIEWS : Too Long a Wait for Rematch of Top 2 Horses |date=November 21, 1989}} Easy Goer is the only horse in history to win the Whitney, Travers, Woodward, and Jockey Club Gold Cup.{{cite web|url=https://www.americasbestracing.net/the-sport/2016-racings-unforgettable-rivalries-sunday-silence-and-easy-goer | location=americasbestracing.net | work=americasbestracing.net | first=Bob | last=Ehalt | title=Racing's Unforgettable Rivalries: Sunday Silence and Easy Goer | date=June 8, 2016 | accessdate=June 16, 2016}} In three of these races, he defeated older horses, becoming one of the few three-year-olds in modern American racing history to do so.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/06/sports/notebook-easy-goer-closing-in-on-a-3-year-old-season-worthy-of-secretariat.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm | work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=NOTEBOOK; Easy Goer Closing In on a 3-Year-Old Season Worthy of Secretariat | date=October 6, 1989}} Only three Hall of Fame champions (Easy Goer, [[Kelso (horse)|Kelso]], and [[Slew o' Gold]]) have ever won the Whitney, Woodward, and Jockey Club Gold Cup in the same year, but Easy Goer was the only three-year-old to complete the triple.{{cite web|url=http://www.brisnet.com/content/2007/09/lawyer-ron-takes-case-to-the-jockey-club-gold-cup/ |location=brisnet.com | work=The Handicapper's Edge | title=Lawyer Ron takes case to the Jockey Club Gold Cup |accessdate=April 27, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.racingmuseum.org/hall-of-fame/easy-goer |location=racingmuseum.org | work=racingmuseum.org | title=hall of fame pade -Easy Goer- racingmuseum.org}} He is one of only two horses to ever win the Champagne, Belmont Stakes, and Travers.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/173191/birdstone-retired-after-suffering-fracture | location=bloodhorse.com | work=bloodhorse.com | first=Steve | last=Haskin | title=Birdstone Retired After Suffering Fracture | date=November 3, 2004 | accessdate=June 16, 2016}} He is also one of only two horses to notch a Travers, Whitney and Belmont Stakes triple, and the only one to do so in the same year.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/aug/07/sports/sp-170 |work=The Los Angeles Times | first=Bob | last=Mieszerski |title=Lemon Drop Kid Scores Sweet Victory in Whitney |date=August 7, 2000 |accessdate=August 8, 2016}} Additionally, he is one of only five horses to tally a Whitney-Travers double in the same year, with the other four being [[Key to the Mint]], [[Eight Thirty]], Alydar and [[Java Gold]]. Since 1919, Easy Goer is one of only ten horses to sweep the Belmont, Travers and Jockey Club Gold Cup.{{cite web|url=http://colinsghost.org/2009/10/summer-bird-wins-jockey-club-gold-cup.html |location=colinsghost.org | work=colinsghost.org | title=Summer Bird wins Jockey Club Gold Cup, 2009 | date=October 5, 2009 |accessdate=June 19, 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://www.drf.com/news/summer-bird-adds-gold-cup-credits | work=Daily Racing Form | first=David | last=Grening | title=Summer Bird adds Gold Cup to credits | date=October 3, 2009 | accessdate=June 19, 2009}} Since 1973, Easy Goer is one of only seven horses that have won three consecutive Grade I races longer than 1 1/8 miles on dirt (or synthetic), with the other six being [[Alysheba]] and [[Gentlemen (horse)|Gentlemen]] as well as Triple Crown winners [[American Pharoah]], Secretariat, [[Seattle Slew]], and [[Affirmed]].{{cite news | url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/features/waiting-and-waiting-for-crowning-glory-629 | work=Blood Horse | first=Frank | last=Angst | title=Waiting, and Waiting, for Crowning Glory | date=May 28, 2014}} He was one of the last American-trained horses to win two Grade I races at a mile and a half on dirt (Belmont Stakes and Jockey Club Gold Cup). Easy Goer's 1989 three-year-old campaign is considered by some to be the greatest in American racing history without yielding any year-end championship awards.http://www.jockeysite.com/stories/easygoer.htm{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/08/sports/horse-racing-easy-goer-surges-to-win-gold-cup.html | work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=HORSE RACING; Easy Goer Surges To Win Gold Cup | date=October 8, 1989}}http://www.hitak.com/home/alydar/easygoer.html With the exception of Horse-of-the-Year the Eclipse Awards are based on age, and from 1971 until the present time the American Champion Older Male Horse award was restricted to male horses aged four years old and up. Prior to 1971 the American Champion Older Male Horse award was referred to as "Champion Handicap Male Horse." The ''Daily Racing Form'' version was open to any horse ages three years old and up, and this award was given to some champions at the age of three, such as [[Citation (horse)|Citation]], [[Buckpasser]], [[Sword Dancer]], [[Damascus (horse)|Damascus]] and [[Arts and Letters]]. The three-year-old Easy Goer conceded weight on scale while defeating top older horses in both the Whitney (G1) and Woodward (G1) Handicaps; defeated leading older horses a third time in the weight-for-age Jockey Club Gold Cup (G1); and beat older horses again in the weight-for-age Breeders' Cup Classic (G1), including the future Champion Older Male Blushing John. Had the awards been categorized as they were prior to 1971, Easy Goer most likely would have been named Champion Handicap Male Horse of 1989. ===1990: four-year-old season=== At four, Easy Goer won the seven-furlong Gold Stage Stakes easily on a sloppy track by over seven lengths, defeating [[Phoenix Stakes (United States)|Phoenix Stakes]] winner Hadif in a final time of 1:22 1/5. Twelve days later, he was third in the Grade I [[Metropolitan Mile]], marking the only time he did not finish either first or second in his career. Easy Goer always had problematic [[fetlock|ankles]], and his handlers had to work overtime on them during the month. Rumors about his soundness had swirled around the track for the two weeks leading into the race.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/sports/criminal-type-outruns-housebuster-and-easy-goer-at-belmont.html |work=The New York Times |first=Steven | last=Crist | title=Criminal Type Outruns Housebuster and Easy Goer at Belmont | date=May 29, 1990}} Easy Goer was beaten by a little more than a length behind eventual Horse of the Year [[Criminal Type]] and two-time sprint champion [[Housebuster]] while carrying considerably more weight than those competitors (fourteen and seven pounds, respectively). Future Horse of the Year and Breeders' Cup Classic winner [[Black Tie Affair]] and two-time [[Vosburgh Handicap]] winner Sewickley finished behind the top three. He then won the mile and a quarter Grade I [[Suburban Handicap]] by almost four lengths [[Glossary of North American horse racing#R|ridden out]] in a time of 2:00 after going head and head on the lead while sprinting through fast fractions of 46.75 for a half-mile and 1:09.87 for six furlongs. He defeated [[Jerome Handicap]] winner De Roche, as well as [[Brooklyn Handicap]] and Stuyvesant Handicap winner Montubio. The final time was 3/5 of a second off [[Alysheba]]'s then track record, which had been set in a weight for age race. Easy Goer conceded {{convert|12|to|19|lb}} to his opponents.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/sports/an-aggressive-easy-goer-wins-suburban.html |work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=An Aggressive Easy Goer Wins Suburban | date=July 5, 1990}} In Easy Goer's 20-race career, he was never defeated by more than 2½ lengths. After his Suburban Handicap win, Easy Goer was retired due to a bone chip in his right front ankle.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/sports/easy-goer-is-retired-after-bone-chip-is-found.html | work=The New York Times | first=Steven | last=Crist | title=Easy Goer Is Retired After Bone Chip Is Found | date=July 19, 1990}} He won 14 races, including 9 Grade I wins, and earned $4,873,770. ==Stud record== After his retirement from racing, Easy Goer stood stud at [[Claiborne Farm]] in Paris, Kentucky. He was given the honor of occupying the number one stall in the number one barn.{{cite news | url=http://articles.philly.com/1994-06-24/sports/25831272_1_fourstars-allstar-easy-goer-race-track | work=The Inquirer | first=Dick | last=Jerardi | title=Reserved For Racing Legends Only Lure Could Earn Claiborne's Coveted Stall | date=June 24, 1994}} His stall was previously occupied by [[Bold Ruler]] and Secretariat. At age eight, in 1994, Easy Goer collapsed and died while jogging in his paddock at Claiborne Farm.{{cite news|last=Lazzarino|first=Chris|title=Easy Goer Collapses, Dies|newspaper=Sun Sentinel|date=May 13, 1994|url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1994-05-13/sports/9405120793_1_easy-goer-trainer-shug-mcgaughey-stakes|accessdate=May 17, 2015}} Dr. Thomas Swerczek, the veterinary pathologist at the [[University of Kentucky]], who conducted Easy Goer's [[necropsy]], determined the horse died of an [[anaphylaxis|anaphylactic]] reaction to an undetermined allergen and also had cancerous tumors in multiple organs. The veterinarians were convinced the cancer did not kill Easy Goer and probably would not have been fatal for a long time. They also said fatal allergic reactions are more common than most professionals realize.{{cite news|last=Lazzarino|first=Chris|title=Gambler keeps placing big bets, but he won't show|newspaper=Sun Sentinel|date=May 29, 1994|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1994-05-29/sports/9405280385_1_easy-goer-show-bets-las-vegas|accessdate=May 13, 2012}} Easy Goer was buried at Claiborne Farm along with Secretariat, [[Buckpasser]], [[Bold Ruler]] and many other greats. At stud, in just a few crops before his premature death, Easy Goer sired three Grade I winners and nine stakes winners (7%), from 136 foals, of which 101 were starters, and 74 were winners. While speed at distances up to a mile had been favored over "stoutness" in much American breeding, Easy Goer demonstrated speed over a mile as well as stamina. Given the combination of his pedigree and the high-quality mares to which he was bred at Claiborne, it was speculated by ''[[The Blood-Horse]]'' that he would have been even more significant as a stallion had he lived longer. Easy Goer has also been an influential broodmare sire. From 53 mares sired by Easy Goer, they have produced 23 stakes winners. ==Notable Offspring== Easy Goer was the sire {{cite news |url=http://www.liontamerllc.com/cgi-bin/links.cgi?0=http://www.liontamerllc.com/pdfs/stallion-register.pdf |work=Blood Horse Publications |title=Stallion Register}} of: * Will's Way - won the Whitney Handicap and Travers Stakes like his sire, and in turn sired Lion Tamer, winner of the [[Cigar Mile Handicap]], [[Hutcheson Stakes]], [[Commonwealth Stakes]], and [[Gulfstream Park Sprint Championship]]. He also sired [[Maryland Sprint Handicap]] winner Willy o'the Valley. * [[My Flag]] - won four Grade I races, including the 1995 [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]], [[Ashland Stakes]], [[Coaching Club American Oaks]] and [[Gazelle Stakes]], as well as the [[Bonnie Miss Stakes]]. She also placed against males in the 1996 Belmont Stakes. My Flag's dam was winner of the 1988 [[Breeders' Cup Distaff]] and 1996 [[Kentucky Broodmare of the Year]] [[Personal Ensign]]. My Flag in turn produced the champion [[Storm Flag Flying]], winner of the 2002 [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]]. She is also the dam of the graded stakes-placed On Parade, dam of multiple graded stakes winner [[Parading (horse)|Parading]], and stakes-winner With Flying Colors, who is the dam of multiple graded stakes winner Teresa Z. * Furlough - won the [[Ballerina Handicap]], [[Distaff Handicap]] and [[Honorable Miss Handicap]]; and is the dam of Stakes Winners Happy Hunting and Pardon. She is also the dam of Pension, dam of [[Futurity Stakes (USA)]] winner Annual Report and Mystic Lake Derby winner Giant Payday. * Composer - won the [[Jim Dandy Stakes]]. * Relaxing Rhythm - won the [[Molly Pitcher Handicap]], [[Torrey Pines Stakes]] and [[Star Shoot Stakes]], and is the dam of graded stakes winner Spring Waltz. * Smooth Charmer - placed in both the [[Shuvee Handicap]] and [[Vagrancy Handicap]], and is the dam of graded stakes winner Sea Chanter. * Promiscuous - won the [[Display Stakes]]. * Jetto - won the [[Honeybee Stakes]]. ==Notable Descendants== Easy Goer is the broodmare sire (maternal grandsire) of: * [[Corinthian (horse)|Corinthian]] - won the [[Breeders' Cup Dirt Mile]], [[Metropolitan Handicap]] and [[Gulfstream Park Handicap]]. * [[Storm Flag Flying]] - Won the [[Eclipse Award]] Championship for top two year old filly and won four Grade I races, including the [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]], [[Frizette Stakes]], [[Matron Stakes (United States)|Matron Stakes]], and [[Personal Ensign Handicap]], as well as the [[Shuvee Handicap]]. * Funny Moon - won the [[Coaching Club American Oaks]] and [[Shuvee Handicap]]. * Monba - won the [[Blue Grass Stakes]]. * [[Astronomer Royal (horse)|Astronomer Royal]] - won the Group I [[Poule d'Essai des Poulains|French 2000 Guineas]] and [[Greenlands Stakes]], and is the sire of [[Athenia Stakes]] and [[Prix des Réservoirs]] Stakes winner Stellar Path. * Magical Fantasy - won four Grade I races, including the [[Yellow Ribbon Stakes]], [[Del Mar Oaks]], [[Gamely Stakes]], and [[John C. Mabee Handicap]], as well as the [[Santa Barbara Handicap]]. * [[Mull of Kintyre (horse)|Mull of Kintyre]] - won the [[Gimcrack Stakes]] in England and sire of [[Araafa]], winner of the [[St. James's Palace Stakes]] and [[Irish 2,000 Guineas]]. * Spring Waltz - won the [[Rampart Handicap]]. * Desert Hero - won the [[San Rafael Stakes]]. * Navesink River - won the [[Pan American Handicap]] and [[Gallant Fox Handicap]]. * Happy Hunting - won the [[Aqueduct Handicap]]. * Sea Chanter - won the [[Miesque Stakes]]. * Sue's Good News - won the [[Arlington Oaks]], and is the dam of [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Turf Sprint]] winner Bulletin and Tiz Miz Sue, who won the [[Ogden Phipps Handicap]] and the [[Azeri Stakes]] twice. * Easy Slam - dam of [[Jessamine Stakes]] winner Kitten Kaboodle. * Kindness - dam of [[Breeders' Cup Marathon]] winner London Bridge. * Fabulous Bonus - dam of [[Go For Wand Handicap]] winner Royal Lahaina. * Unbridled Jet - placed in the [[Pegasus Stakes]] and [[Long Branch Stakes]], and ranked among the leading sires in [[New Jersey]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/63966/nj-stallion-unbridled-jet-dies |work=Bloodhorse.com |title=NJ Stallion Unbridled Jet dies |date=July 11, 2011}} * Easyfromthegitgo - won the [[Iowa Derby]] and [[Lecomte Stakes]]. * Nolan's Cat - placed in the 2005 Belmont Stakes, [[Super Derby]] and [[Dominion Day Stakes]]. * Easy Grades - placed in the [[Santa Anita Derby]] and San Rafael Stakes. * Unbridled Secret - dam of [[Barbara Fritchie Handicap]] winner My Wandy's Girl, who also was a champion three year old in [[Puerto Rico]]. * On Parade - dam of [[Dixie Stakes]] and [[Ben Ali Stakes]]-winner [[Parading (horse)|Parading]]; Parading sired Dragon Bay, winner of the [[Nijinsky Stakes]] and [[Eclipse Stakes (Canada)|Eclipse Stakes]]. * Pension - dam of [[Futurity Stakes (USA)]] winner Annual Report and Mystic Lake Derby winner Giant Payday. * Dead Aim - dam of [[Fair Grounds Oaks]] and [[Delta Princess Stakes]] winner Quiet Temper. * Throng - winner of the [[Native Dancer Stakes]]. * With Flying Colors - stakes-winning dam of multiple graded stakes winner Teresa Z, winner of the [[Turnback The Alarm Handicap]], [[Monmouth Oaks]] and [[Obeah Stakes]]. * Silver Ticket - won the [[King Edward Stakes]] and [[Toronto Cup Stakes]]. * Fahamore - dam of Blue Devil Bel, who is the dam of Audible, winner of the Grade I [[Florida Derby]] and [[Holy Bull Stakes]]; Fahamore is also the dam of stakes winner Akilina, who is the dam of stakes winners Governor Malibu and Rieno Tesoro.{{cite web |url=http://www.nytbreeders.org/news/2016/12/16/rieno-tesoro-zennippon-nisai-yushun/ |work=New York Thoroughbred Breeders, Inc. |title=Undefeated New Yorker Rieno Tesoro making a big splash in Japan |date=December 16, 2016}} ==Honors and Assessments== In 1997, Easy Goer was inducted into the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame]].{{cite web | url=https://www.racingmuseum.org/hall-of-fame/easy-goer |work=racingmuseum.org/hall-of-fame |title=Easy Goer| date=2016}} In the [[Blood-Horse magazine]] ranking of the [[Blood-Horse magazine List of Top 100 Racehorses of the 20th Century|top 100 U.S. Thoroughbred champions of the 20th Century]], Easy Goer was ranked # 34. Easy Goer won the Eclipse Award as American champion 2-year-old male in 1988. Easy Goer graces the cover of the 2005 book, "Belmont Park: A Century of Champions," with paintings by Richard Stone Reeves and text by Edward L. Bowen. Belmont Park, the renowned racetrack, has played host to some of Thoroughbred racing's greatest champions, from [[Man o' War]] and [[Citation (horse)|Citation]] to Secretariat and [[Cigar (horse)|Cigar]]. Belmont Park is known as "The Championship Track" because nearly every major American champion in racing history has competed on the racetrack. The book chronicles seventy racehorses who competed from 1905 to 2005 thrilling fans, setting records, and becoming legends at the venerable New York track.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LhVVOWZ5QR0C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Belmont Park: A Century of Champions |publisher=Eclipse Press Blood-Horse publications |author=Edward L. Bowen and Richard Stone Reeves |accessdate=June 13, 2016}} Easy Goer's rivalry with Sunday Silence was featured as the 17th chapter of Horse Racing's Greatest Rivalries (2008, Eclipse Press), a compilation produced by the staff of The Blood-Horse. Easy Goer's duel with Sunday Silence in the 1989 Preakness was ranked #70 in Horse Racing's Top 100 Moments, a review of racing in the 20th century compiled by The Blood-Horse and released in 2006. Easy Goer was retrospectively awarded a [[Timeform]] rating of 137 pounds which was tied with his arch-rival Sunday Silence for second place among American runners of the 20th century. Only Cigar at 138 pounds was rated higher.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanclassicpedigrees.com/easy-goer.html |location=americanclassicpedigrees.com |title=Easy Goer (USA) |date=2014–2016 |accessdate=June 13, 2016}} Easy Goer was one of thirty champion Thoroughbreds inducted into the Saratoga Hoofprints Walk of Fame as part of the inaugural class in 2013. The Saratoga Hoofprints Walk of Fame is designed to pay homage to the most accomplished thoroughbreds to compete at [[Saratoga Race Course]] during its 150-year history. It honors the most prolific and notable horses to have raced at one of the nation's most historic tracks.{{cite web |url=http://www.saratoga150.com/history/hoofprints/ |location=saratoga150.com |title=Hoofprints Walk of Fame at Saratoga Race Course |date=2013}} The Easy Goer Stakes run every Belmont Stakes day at Belmont Park is named in his honor.{{cite web |url=https://www.nyra.com/belmont/racing/stakes-schedule/winstar-farm-easy-goer/ |work=nyra.com/belmont/stakes-race/winstar-farm-easy-goer/ |title=Easy Goer |date=2016}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} * [http://www.pedigreequery.com/easy+goer Easy Goer's pedigree and photo] * [https://www.racingmuseum.org/hall-of-fame/easy-goer Easy Goer's page in the Hall of Fame] * [http://www.hitak.com/home/alydar/easygoer.html] * [http://www.jockeysite.com/stories/easygoer.htm] * [https://query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch?query=easy+goer&more=date_all Search for Easy Goer articles in the New York Times] * [http://articles.nydailynews.com/1997-08-05/sports/18056890_1_easy-goer-muddy-churchill-downs-track-ogden-phipps] * [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/sports/on-horse-racing-closing-the-chapter-on-easy-goer.html?scp=6&sq=easy%20goer%20secretariat&st=cse] ==External links== * [http://helloracefans.com/horses/horse-profiles/easy-goer/ Easy Goer Profile at Hello Race Fans] {{Belmont Stakes Winners}} [[Category:1986 racehorse births]] [[Category:1994 racehorse deaths]] [[Category:Racehorses bred in Kentucky]] [[Category:Racehorses trained in the United States]] [[Category:Belmont Stakes winners]] [[Category:Eclipse Award winners]] [[Category:United States Thoroughbred Racing Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Phipps family]] [[Category:American Grade 1 Stakes winners]] [[Category:Thoroughbred family 1-x]]

{{refimprove|date=June 2013}} '''Enrique Sarasola Lerchundi''' (24 August 1937 – 2 November 2002) was a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[business magnate|industrialist]], a major figure in his country's transition to [[democracy]],{{cn|date=October 2015}} and an owner and [[horse breeding|breeder]] of [[Thoroughbred]] [[horse racing|racehorses]].
A native of [[Donostia|San Sebastian]], [[Spain]], at age twenty, Sarasola emigrated to [[Colombia]] as an [[audit|auditor]] with [[Price Waterhouse]]. He married Cecilia Marulanda, from a wealthy family, and eventually went into business for himself. Highly successful, in 1970 he returned to his native Spain where he became active in politics. Working behind the scenes where political opposition was suppressed by the government of [[General Franco]], Sarasola used his wealth to help the then illegal [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]] (PSOE) headed by [[Felipe Gonzalez]]. After Gonzalez was elected [[Prime Ministers of the Spanish government|Prime Minister of the Spanish government]] in 1982, Enrique Sarasola became a powerful figure during Gonzalez' fourteen years in office.<ref>{{es}} [http://www.transicionestructural.net/index.php?topic=709.0 La Gran Cloaca (II). Enrique Sarasola Lerchundi y otras hierbas]</ref><ref>{{es}} [https://puntosinapsis.wordpress.com/2016/11/24/las-relaciones-del-narco-escobar-con-el-expresidente-espanol-felipe-gonzalez/ Las relaciones del narco Pablo Escobar con el expresidente español Felipe González]</ref><ref>{{es}} [https://espiaenelcongreso.com/2014/12/10/felipe-gonzalez-se-va-colombia-nacionalizado-con-sus-amigos-narcopoliticos-una-comision-de-19-millones/ Felipe González se va a Colombia nacionalizado con sus amigos “narcopolíticos”: una comisión de 19 millones]</ref> However, he would come under much criticism and be involved in court battles over charges of [[patronage]] and [[political corruption]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Sarasola niega ante el juez haber participado en el metro de Medellin |url=https://elpais.com/diario/1996/06/29/economia/835999206_850215.html |publisher=EL PAIS}}</ref>
Enrique Sarasola owned a number of successful racehorses, the best known of which was [[Helissio]], winner of the 1996 [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] and [[Cartier Racing Award|European Horse of the Year]]. From 1992 until its closure in 1996, Sarasola was the owner of Hipodromo de la Zarzuela [[race track]], just west of Madrid.<ref>[http://www.jockeysroom.com/msg20.htm La Zarzuela Racetrack, Spain]</ref><ref> {{es}} {{cite web|url=http://actualidad.orange.es/nacional/herederos-sarasola-tendran-que-pagar-34-millones-al-grupo-torras.html|title=Los herederos de Enrique Sarasola Lerchundi tendrán que pagar 34 millones al Grupo Torras noticias Nacional actualidad|accessdate=2 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120602183452/http://actualidad.orange.es/nacional/herederos-sarasola-tendran-que-pagar-34-millones-al-grupo-torras.html|archive-date=2 June 2012 }}</ref>
After a long illness, Enrique Sarasola died at age 65 in 2002 in a [[Madrid]] hospital and was interred in the La Paz-Alcobendas cemetery in Madrid.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-03-11-2002/abc/Nacional/muere-en-madrid-a-los-65-a%C3%B1os-de-edad-el-empresario-guipuzcoano-enrique-sarasola_140850.html|title=Muere a los 65 años de edad el empresario guipuzcoano Enrique Sarasola|last=|first=|date=|work=ABC|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> His son, [[:es:Kike Sarasola|Enrique Sarasola, Jr.]], is a world class [[equestrianism|equestrian]] competitor who has represented Spain in the 1998 [[Eventing World Championship]] and the [[2000 Summer Olympics]]. His relative [[Javier Moll]] is a notable media mogul.

An '''entrepreneurial company with limited liability''' (in German: Unternehmergesellschaft (haftungsbeschränkt)) is a [[Germany|German]] form of a [[private limited company]], usually established as an alternative to a [[Aktiengesellschaft|German corporation]] or [[Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung|GmbH]] (limited liability) entity. Companies organized as an entrepreneurial company have the suffix ‘''UG (haftungsbeschränkt)''’ appended to their names.
== Background == The German government introduced the UG primarily to act as an alternative to establishing a traditional corporation.<ref>BGH, Urteil vom 27. September 1999 - II ZR 371/98</ref> A UG established under German law is not a new type of [[Legal personality|legal entity]]; rather, it is a limited liability company similar to a GmbH, with the exception that, unlike the GmbH, it is not required to meet the legally mandated €25,000 share capital required of a GmbH—a UG can be established with as little as one euro of paid-in capital. However, a UG is still a separate legal entity from its owners and is fully liable for paying [[Income tax|corporation taxes]] and publishing annual [[financial statement]]s. UG entities can be recognized as not-for-profit, under the right conditions.
The UG form has been met with great interest, especially by [[Startup company|start-up companies]] and other entrepreneurs. As of January 1, 2012, there had been 64,371 of such companies formed. Since then, traditional corporations have been reduced in importance, having largely been supplanted by the UG (and also the GmbH) among new companies being formed.<ref>''Kornblum:'' In: ''GmbH-Rundschau.'' 2012, S. 728.</ref>
== Formation and requirements == Forming a UG is relatively similar to forming a closely related GmbH entity, however the UG is exempt from some of the capital rules applicable to a GmbH.
=== Company name === The company must bear the title “Unternehmergesellschaft (haftungsbeschränkt)” or, as an abbreviated form, “UG (haftungsbeschränkt)” (§ 5a GmbHG). ''Unternehmergesellschaft'' means entrepreneurial company and the German word ''haftungsbeschränkt'' means “limited liability”.<ref>[http://www.streifflaw.de''Streiff:'' Starting a business in Germany], Berlin 2017</ref> It signifies the fact that the owners of the company have limited liability for the company’s debts.
=== Share capital === The nominal amount of the business’ shares - the so-called "[[Share capital|ordinary capital]]" - as defined in the [[Partnership agreement|company agreement]], must be provided after the foundation of the company and before its registration into the commercial register ( [https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?act=url&depth=1&hl=en&ie=UTF8&prev=_t&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=auto&sp=nmt4&tl=en&u=https://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/gmbhg/__5a.html&usg=ALkJrhhmTYUQ3Nd6ktVNVnZqC8u4zo0Tcw § 5a] para 2 GmbHG). The total capital stock must be at least one euro. In practice, amounts of up to €1,000 are usually chosen.
If the total amount of share capital exceeds EUR 25,000, then a GmbH is usually formed instead of a UG. (§ 5a para. 1 p. 1 GmbHG). In contrast to the GmbH form, no contribution in kind is permitted for a UG. The share capital must be paid immediately in full as a cash contribution (§ 5a (2) GmbHG). If capital of EUR 12,500 is available, either a UG (limited liability) with a share capital of EUR 12,500 can be established, or a limited liability company in the original sense, in which only half of the share capital of at least EUR 25,000 has to be paid.
== References == <references />
